While vocational education was originally included in public education as a means to teach those not academically inclined the present illusion that these programs are as good as they are promoted is questionable. While I even participated in a number of such courses, not a complete immersion, what is presented and what is actually available is often a problem due to costs. The typical offerings are done with students spending half time in one school and being bussed to another place for the vocational program. In some cases the students are even required to attend school year round, not bad, but transportation becomes costly to a school district. My point? The present arrangement of local schools, small and with a limited budget, makes it a problem for those students, however, Urban school districts with money being thrown at them would seem to cover such costs, but then there are the remedial programs in such places. Money is always in short supply, perhaps because of politics and when such solutions emerge it is often with another administrative structure in which those at such places are paid a premium for their services, again money is required so the siphon from smaller districts is heard. Of course the other problem, not acknowledged, is what happens to the student if the vocational education pathway chosen folds in a community or if there is an oversupply of such students for a limited number of jobs.
